turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments first this morning in Michigan v. Tyler and Tompkins.
Mr. Butler you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: This Arson case presents the questions of when and to what extend of warrant is to be required for post fire and by analogy other post disaster investigations and of which evidence is admissible against in particular arsonists who burn their own buildings.
The case arises as out of facts which were the most part are typical of any arson for profit case with two small exceptions which we plan to elaborate upon later in argument.
In relating the facts and in attempting to justify, a warrant was post fire searches in general as well as the searches which occurred in particular in this case.
We have four principle themes.

The first is that the public interest in a post disaster or post fire search is significantly greater than the public interest in any inspection of the type touched upon and dealt with in Camara, say and Secretary of State against Barlow.
The second theme is that the privacy interests at issue as well as the potential for abuse are very minimal, primarily because of the extensive damage that has taken place.
The extent of the already lawful intrusion and because of the nature of the search for the cause or the origin of the fire.

Third, we contend that a warrant in circumstances like these whether administrative or criminal will provide no protection in the great majority of cases, very little protection in a very limited class of cases.
Our fourth theme is that, a fire investigation, there are certain costs, in fire investigation and in public safety to require any kind of administrative search warrant.
The general interest in a search, in conducting a search of this type are several.
The cause itself must be determined first as some type of exigent circumstance.
This is a theme which the Michigan Supreme Court seem not to acknowledge.

Now we grant that, it did say if there are exigent circumstances, the possibility of danger, of evidence burning, of danger to the fireman conducting the investigation, danger of water damage to the evidence that then they will excuse us a search that takes place at that time, but we think they should have concluded that until the clause is determined there should be a presumption if there is an exigent circumstance.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In the local law applicable here, is every fire subject to some investigation as to cause?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: There is a local statue which requires the local fire marshal to determine that conduct a physical investigation to determine a cause or origin of fire, and it states that he may enter without warrant any premises for making that determination.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, now the Statue says, the State Statute says that the Director or any Officer is authorized to investigate and inquire, it does not direct him to --

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: If not that specific Statute, it is clear that under the fire Prevention Act, he does have the duty to determine the cause or origin of all fires that result in property damage or death.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And did you say in an answer to the question of Chief Justice that he does in fact investigate the cause or origin of every single fire, large and small?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: The Statute reads where there is injury or damage to property, he would have to investigate any fire that is called to his attention, very small fires that you would never hear of course --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is this Statue is simply an authorizing Statute.
It is a not a directory Statute.
But you say that in practice he will be under a duty to do it?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And does do it?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes he does Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In every case where there is loss of life or damage to property.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: That is brought to his attention.
Now it is a very small fire that, I mean of course that is never reported to any fire department.
No he does not do that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well I am assuming it been reported to fire department.
There is always damage to property in a fire, isn't there?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Not always to real property.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then say real property.
Pretty hard a damage real property in fire.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: I am saying real property, the building as well Your Honor, that is determined by that term.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did not the Michigan Court construe the State Statute?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We believe that he construed the State Statute to require a warrant only to make it Constitutional under the Fourth Amendment.
But they did read a warrant requirement in to that Statute.

We claim that it makes very little sense to do that because it is simply not the intent of the Legislature because they surely should be presumed to know that any fire investigator can (Inaudible) with the warrant, so by very clear implications, it would seem that the Statute on states would seem to allow warrant searches.
That is the Court said the Statute did not speak to the question.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That are quite rebound by the Michigan construction.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: I do not believe--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: To the extent that is relevant to this case.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: I do not believe it will be bound by, if their construction depended upon an erroneous view only the Fourth Amendment.
If it depended upon any another view of Michigan law then the Court would be bound by it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: This is not the only reason the case is here, is it because they have construed the federal constitution?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes it is Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Butler, did I correctly understand your view is that the exigent circumstances exception should survive until the cause of the fire is determined?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Precisely Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even if it might take a year or two?
If the building has been reconstructed, would it still survive that long?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Not if the owner occupant had somehow re-taken over the premises and moved something back in or any other way it indicated that he is either living in them or using it as an operational--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What if he just locks the premises and secures them against entry by third parties?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: A lot of that would depend upon precisely when he did that.
We contend that fire --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would that ever terminate the exigency exception.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes it certainly would at some point we can--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But can we do that in this case?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: No in this case the proprietor of the premises was out of state for about seven days after the fire.
Until about seven days after the fire--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But at the time of the search where they found that the fuse and the glass or whatever it was, some 22 or 23 days later, the premises were locked were they not?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: They were locked and sealed by the Fire Department --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, why did that not terminate the exigency then?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: It clearly did -- by the time of that search the exigency was terminated.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then under your view of the law the search was improper, if I understand you?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: No Your Honor we attempt -- we believe there is additional justification for that search.
We are speaking now primarily of the search that occurred the morning following the fire.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes but some of the evidence that was excluded, I mean it was received over objection, it was found on January 22 or whatever date it was, about three or four weeks later.
Don't you have to sustain that search in order to sustain the conviction?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We had to sustain that search, yes Your Honor, but we do not believe we have to sustain it under the exigent circumstances exception to the warrant requirement.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Who put the lock on the door?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: The Fire Department perhaps in conjunction with the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The seal depending the completion of the investigation as I read the record is that correct?
Building was sealed by a lock put on it by the Fire Marshal both to protect the property and during the course of his investigation is that correct?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, the fire was put out at approximately 4 a.m. on January 22 at which time the fire department boarded up all the windows and put their own locks and chains on all the doors and then re-entered at eight o' clock, the next morning, and found what we agreed was indeed the cause of the fire by that time.

The Michigan Supreme Court held that in the course of putting out the fire between midnight and approximately 4 a.m on January 22nd that the finding only of two plastic bottles, one partially filled with gasoline was itself the cause of the fire and that enabled them, that gave them enough probable cause to obtain a search warrant, we are contending that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Butler, I want to be sure.
Are there not three pieces of evidence here, the first what they picked up at the time of the fire, that is plastic container --

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And there was no objection to its submission as I recall.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: At least it is – it was not challenged in the Court below and nor here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The second piece was what was discovered at the day light entry the very next day.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that was submitted over objection and is at issue here.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And then the third one, am I correct was two or three weeks later?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: About three or four weeks later there was a re-entry, the reason for the re-entry was that the photographs taken by an arson investigator were lost in the mail.
He apparently re-entered to retake some odd photographs and while doing that found a piece of fuse and pieces of glass and debris and those items were admitted in--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But in any event we have these three levels of evidence, two of which are under challenge at this court.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: That is correct Your Honor however in order to make this case re-triable under the opinion of the Michigan Supreme Court really there were other entries into the building and the principles of the opinion below would not allow for example, oral testimony by an arson investigator who went in four days after the fire.
Had he taken photographs or found physical evidence, it is clear that they would have been challenged.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: When you talk about a warrant requirement as imposed by the Michigan Supreme court here, what inquiry would the magistrate make in order to justify the issue on civil warrant.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: The only possible inquiry which we can imagine is simply whether or not a fire occurred.
It seems that if an search warrant is to be allowed is to required to re-enter and determine the cause or origin of the fire, all that we should be able to have to show is that a fire occurred.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, couldn't he show that there were two cans of gasolines in that?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Well,we can show that the fire occurred by the condition of the building.
I mean that is what we say that the fire occurred.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, couldn't you show that?
I mean you do not have gasoline sitting around for fumigation purposes, do you?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: I am not sure if Your Honors is suggesting that we need a criminal warrant, if that is the case then there is close question of whether those two bottles of gasoline are sufficient to prove that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I am talking about the warrant.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: If we think if just an administrative warrant is required to determine the cause or origin of the fire, then the only --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You keep saying re-entry, by that you mean search, are you (Inaudible) the word search?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: No, we are not, we have used repeatedly throughout the brief that I --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It stated here that you are saying re-entry and I mean the term, you keep saying entry.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Well, the entry is one intrusion and what they do inside is something else.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But did they not search when they went in?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes, they did, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Each time.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes, they did, it searched for the cause or origin of the fire.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And when you say that do you mean search?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Interim search.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you be satisfied of the rule that you could enter the building any time you wanted to after a fire, and hunt for evidence and the cause but then nothing you found could be admitted an evidence in the criminal prosecution unless you had a warrant?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: No, we would be very dissatisfied with the rule like that Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You really want to gather to any evidence, aren't you?
It is a criminal investigation among other thing.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Among other things exactly Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, why is this arson crime any different than any other crime in terms of your ability to enter property to find evidence.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We think it is different because there is a legitimate need to enter the property anyway, to make a valid civil inspection and search for the cause of the fire.
Another respect in which it is different is that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I know but you could server that in by agreeing not to use the evidence in the criminal prosecution, unless you had a warrant.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: That would be the most perverse imaginable Your Honor because that would say, and it is alright to make these searches because there is a public interest for them, but we are making one exception and give a benefit only to arsonists and say that the evidence can not be --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but you are saying that only arsonists can object to entry, to a property without a warrant.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We are saying that a arsonists are in a special class and that the way they have treated their own property, suggests that they have no protectable interest and no interest remaining protected by the Fourth Amendment by nearly any test except one which requires total abandonment of any property interests --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Like a man who shoots his children?
He is done something pretty bad, that you can not enter his house and search his property without a warrant, just to find evidence of the crime?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: It is true Your Honor, we are not contending that he somehow as punishment for his crime loses a right.
We would make the same analysis, if arson for profit were not a crime.
Our point is that the way he treats his own property, the actions which make up the crime of arson also speak to what expectation he has in his own premises, and they say that he has none.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: To extend my brother White's question, and if a man shoots and kills four people in a place, you can not come in and investigate that , but if he burns him up you can.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: If we see a gun shot in a building and I think they can usually go in without a warrant, just because --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, if is that a silencer?
Just to make it tough.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Just because a crime is then committed in a building does not waive any kind of privacy or protection--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Except the arson.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Except the arson of your own building.

We think that the deliberate destruction of someone's owned property is so inconsistent with any notion of how the law is supposed to protect private property, that in itself would be sufficient to waive at least temporarily any Fourth Amendment protection in the arsonists owned building.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Butler I would like to go back to Mr. Justice Rehnquist's question, just what does a magistrate do if you have to get a warrant, if you went to prove a fire took place and some damage was incurred, isn't he automatically going to issue the warrant?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: That is precisely our point, Your Honor, that needs no exercise in terms of --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is only on the assumption that you need not show probable cause to believe that a crime has been committed.
Whereas if you assume that while you have assumed the case away.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Okay, if we are speaking of administrative warrants, then you do not need any probable cause to show that a crime has occurred.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well that is -- you are assuming the case away again.
When the Marshall begins, is he looking for a crime or is he looking for a cause of a fire?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: He is looking for the cause of a fire, which may--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And incidentally, he may then come to the conclusion later that it was self-inflicted, that is, that it was arson, but does it become a criminal investigation, right at the outset?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Not at the outset, it cannot.

The point is once there is evidence of arson discovered, it becomes -- arson is still a cause of a fire and as far as using fire experience as a yard stick to test the success of fire codes that says that this was not a breakdown of the fire prevention system.
This was deliberately cause.
But, at the same time, of course, it is evidence of a crime.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, can the medical examiner go into a house to find the cause of the death?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes, he can, immediately.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I know but without a warrant, five days later, can he -- the door is locked, can he break in?
And find the evidence of what killed the person.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: I would think in almost any circumstances, yes.
Your Honor --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Without a warrant?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Speaking of an exigent circumstance where a body is discovered that appears to have died of unnatural causes, it -- now he cannot break into an occupied home.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay, does he needs a warrant or does he not?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Your Honor those factors--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Private house, private property?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: It would depend --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All it was to find out, is a cause of death, we are saying that it maybe very much, a great evidence of the crime.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: It is very difficult to imagine circumstances that would arise where that he would have noticed somehow that there is a dead body that has been dead for five days and yet it is in a completely locked house where someone is denying admission to the public.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No question about somebody, about -- no question that somebody's died, the body is in a morgue but the medical examiner would like to get into somebody's house to find out what killed him?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Oh, no clearly not Your Honor, I misunderstood the question, I thought the body was in the house.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why cannot he go in the house and find out the cause of death, that is all he wants to know.
He is supposed to make out a death certificate.
He does not know, so he would like to go find out.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We are dealing with a fully occupied home or business that has all the traditional Fourth Amendment protection.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, if this person had locked and when this fire was put out and put his own locks on his premises, would there warrant have to be obtained to get in?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Under most circumstances we would say, yes.
On the other hand --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How about this circumstance, if he had locked them, if he had locked the door, the fireman put the fire out and went away and instead of the fire department putting locks – locking it up, he did.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We still contend that if we are going to look at how he treats the property, that is by putting a lock on it, we should also look at what he has done to the property to bring it into that condition, he has deliberately destroyed it.
He has attempted to sell it back to the insurance company involuntarily, which indicates he does not want it any more.
He is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I do not think he has done anything, yet he had been indicted to --

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Whenever the issue is raised in a suppression hearing or on appeal, the Court will always have before it the facts which indicate what he did.
It is his guilt, this will be established to some legal degree.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: It is true that at the time they entered, they may not have the evidence, that occupant burned it himself, that is true, we are saying --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But in this case, he had an evidence that he had two cans of gasoline?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: That maybe evidence of arson, I am not sure its evidence that he burnt that he did himself.
It could have been a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But there is -- where is the evidence of arson?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We think that is very slim evidence of arson, we doubt that a warrant would ever issue simply upon a statement that two plastic bottles of gasoline were found in a burned building, that seems equally --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: is consistent with innocent fire as --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But what was this building?
Manufacturing plant?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it was retail furniture store.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But, what do they use gasoline for?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Cleaning, at the time they just cleaned the building --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Ah, I see.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: It was hydrocarbon or some kind of flammable liquid.
It did smell gasoline in the building, those seem to be the only facts which indicated that the fire was arson.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Butler, does the record tell us, at the time of the search on February 16th, the building was locked as I understand it, who had keys to the building at that time?
Just the fire people or did the -- did the --

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: I believe it is just the fire and or the police officials had keys to the building, at that time the respondent Tyler had returned from out of State and I believe January 29th, that is when he visited the premises and I do not -- nothing in the record indicates that he had a key to it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: There is nothing that I was able to find.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you distinguish at all between business premises and a home for purposes of your argument?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We have it in the briefs -- no we do not, Your Honor, we would of course concede that if there had been any fire in a home and the people are still living there or the damage was not extensive that yes a warrant should be obtained there.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did you hear argument in the Osha case yesterday in this court?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr, Butler let me add to your troubles if I may.
As you know we take the state law as construed by the court of the state.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We have no other choice.
My question is suggested by an earlier question by my brother Powell.

In this case the supreme court of Michigan pointed out that the statute itself is silent as to a warrant requirement, it does not say when it is is required does not say when it is not required but it said as the state court, we are now construing the law, the State law of Michigan as requiring a warrant.

Now, therefore, do not we have before us a state law as construed by the Highest Court of your State that in fact requires a warrant in this situation and if that is true is there any federal question before this court.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We contend that they construe it only to meet what they believe to be the requirements of Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They did construe their state law as requiring a warrant in these situations.
The statute and then we take the combination of what was enacted by the legislature and construction of it put on it by the Michigan Courts.
And the Michigan Courts now tell us that the law of the State of Michigan as a matter of state law requires a warrant in this situation.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: But they are doing it only to do what they believe what is necessary to conform the Federal constitution requirement.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How they did it maybe they could not read but however they did it this is what they tell us the state law requires.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We contend that construing a statute to make it meet constitutional requirements is itself a federal question not a state question, if their construction of the Fourth Amendment's requirements is mistaken then they would presumably they would revise their judgment of what Michigan (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We have the Zakini case late last term which I thinks supports your position.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: I am not familiar with the case with case I am sorry.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Butler, supposing the state legislature had expressly drafted a statute requiring a warrant and the legislative history showed that legislatures only did it because they thought the Federal Constitution required it.

They said we really do not want this requirement we think the Supreme Court will impose it on us, could we ignore that statute because they acted under a misguided interpretation of Federal Constitution.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: No we could not Your Honor they would have bound by that, of course that would be a state law, because of it is a legislative act rather than a Court's decision or court judgment that could be reviewed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But here you are saying that even though the States Supreme Court is clear and what it tells us the statute means we should change that because we think they may have acted on an incorrect premise.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We are asking this court to if it agrees with our position state that the federal constitution does not require this construction.
It does not require a warrant.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If they had to place their decision exclusively on Michigan law, would you be here.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: No we would not be Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Under the Ker case decided by this Court some years ago whenever we have been in doubt about whether the state court acted on federal or state grounds we have sent the case back to require the state Supreme Court or its highest Court to state clearly whether they acted under federal or state law but here they did place it on the Fourth Amendment did they not?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes they did Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And that is why you claim your right to be here.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes it is.

Our contention is that there will be no protection afforded by the administrative warrant because it should issue simply on the fact of fire occurring, there seems to be no need for any exercise of independent judgment, no real individual review by a magistrate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is your basis for that?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: That if the only question is did a fire occur.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there some established law around that says that you need not show the probable cause to believe the crime has been committed?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: I believe the administrative warrant requirement which the court below imposed did not have anything to do with whether a crime had occurred.
It had simply to do with whether a fire had occurred and the officials need to reenter the premises.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What you are talking about what the federal constitution does or does not require, what authority is there for saying that under the Fourth Amendment you can investigate an arson by entering property without showing probable cause.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We think Camara stands for the proposition that you can have inspections without showing necessarily a crime has occurred.
You have to show their reasonableness by criteria which really do not apply to a post disaster investigation.
The length of time since a final last inspection has occurred is irrelevant, the only think that is relevant is the condition of the building.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Camara, you say that your principle cases.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We are contending that they do not require an administrative search warrant even though--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Even in an investigation we have a criminal investigation.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: We contend we have a some kind of mixture of both Your Honor.
But to the extent --.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what in the world reason do you have to go in unless you want to find out whether or not a crime had been committed?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: You still want to find, confirm the cause of the fire.
It was done in a very hasty manner in this case if it is contended --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Estimated three weeks later?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Now, speaking of them, leaving at 4 a.m. and being satisfied, that they have determined the cause of the fire simply by finding two bottles of gasoline or nearly that does not seem sufficient.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well then after that all that time, they could think up getting a warrant?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: It seems the reason they left was simply because there was no more they could do until day light, until smoke and steam had dissipated and they were able to --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And until they could have gotten a warrant, there could have been another reason?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: There were four hours and that is the rough time that even an administrative want which requires really no exercise of judgment would take so administrative warrant perhaps could have been obtained had there been the requirement at the time of the search.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, even if they had found nothing, even if they had not found these two cans of gasoline might they not have wanted to go back feeling that they had not determined the cause of fire even though perhaps there was no arson involved?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes Sir, I believe they would have gone back to continue their investigation in daylight hours to do whatever they could not do at night while the building was filled with smoke and steam.
In addition they need to just check the structure or integrity of any of the building even before letting the occupants back in.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We are just suggesting perhaps some of us that you do not necessarily have a crime involved so far as investigation is concerned.

Is that not the duty of the Fire Department under your system to find out the cause of a fire among other things to prevent its recurrence under similar circumstances, there might be no arson involved?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: Yes it is Your Honor.
Determine the cause of the fire, to determine the extent of the damage and to check the structure or integrity of the building.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It strikes me you have something not dissimilar to an internal revenue service investigation that initially might be all just to determine that everything has been included and that develop into a full fledged criminal investigation.
Sometimes depending on what they find.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_butler
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey Butler
turn.text: It is correct Your Honor.
If there are no for the questions, if the court please, as to reserve my remaining time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Bacalis.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
I think I would like to begin my remarks by clarifying the factual record a little bit.
Allow me to say that the fire occurred at about 11:30, or just before 12 'O' clock on January 21st.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: At night?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: At night.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Then while the Fire Department was there until 4 a.m. on January 22nd, a lieutenant lost and then the Fire Department discovered gasoline on the premises and he thereupon called the attention to Chief See who was the Fire chief.
He came over and found the gasoline.

At that point Chief See then brought in Detective Webb and he too looked at the gasoline and at that point they removed the gasoline from the premises and went to the Police Headquarters and poured the gasoline that they had removed from the premises into another container which was marked for evidence purposes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now do you say that is, that is was a proper taking of possession of that gasoline?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I have to concede that the Fire Department had a right to be there to put off fire and whatever they found in the course of being there present for that occasion.
They had a right to seize it.
That much--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well they certainly did not have a right to permanently take whatever they found there, did they?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No but, they have a right to at least identify it as being cause for determining what the cause and origin of the fire was.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: One of the reason they would remove the gasoline if they thought it was gasoline so that they fire might not reignite between four in the morning and daylight I suppose, would they not?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I can only tell the court what they did.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well does it not make sense?
We are dealing with the clause that has a word reasonable in it, unreasonable as a matter of fact.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I think we have to deal with the explosive nature and the danger of gasoline being present in premises just because it vaporises.
From that context there is a danger present just because gasoline is vaporising.

I would have to concede yes, there is a danger present whether that is the motive that prompted the police officer and the fireman to move the gasoline from the premises, I can not say, all I can tell you is what they did.

My own private opinion is that we are gathering evidence because as they indicate under cross-examination, they admitted that at point in time, before they left the premises at 4 a.m., they had determined the cause and origin of the fire.
And that the gasoline was the cause and origin of the fire.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You said they, who is they?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: The persons I have identified, Chief See who is fire chief and --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is he an expert to find a cause of fire?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: In my opinion, he is not an expert but I am telling you what he determined--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you said they determine the cause.
What would they determine, if they are not experts.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well, if your honor please, the general practice is in fire extinguishment that some body make a determination of cause and origin, that is usually done by the fire department personnel.
Now, whether or not they are experts and qualified to make that judgment--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, the answer is if they determined it why did they have other investigation, and they had other investigation because they had not determined it.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well, I do not think so Your Honor.
My personal opinion is that they once they determined that gasoline was involved.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did they have a marshal that is solely responsible for determining the cause of fires?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: In state we do -- we have a state fire marshal.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is his responsibility now I do not see a Chief of police or Chief of fire department can take up his responsibility, that is my problem.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well I can not vouch for why they did your honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why don't you say that they said that was the cause.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Oh absolutely.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well no you said they say they found, they found you know what I mean?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: They testified they had determined the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Testified fine.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: They testified that they determine that gasoline.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They testified that in their opinion.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: That is right.
That is correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now that would to be required certainly to take away any Incendiary material and I suppose there were couple of cases of bourbon or couple of cases of shotgun shells, would it make any sense for them, to leave them in a fire that had not been totally and fully extinguished.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: In the state of Michigan, the only one who removes liquor from premises is the department who administers alcohol licensing, Michigan Liquor Control Commission.
The liquor is destroyed under their direction.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No I am not talking about destroying you know.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I am talking about removing, it also possesses what your honor asked.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would not the fire marshal, would not the fire department have the authority to remove inflammable material that might re-ignite the fire?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I think one could well hypothicate, he has a duty to protect further danger from developing, yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He would not be thought to have much sense if he did not remove it would he?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I can not vouch for that, Your Honor because all I can tell you is what they generally do and in Michigan they do generally not remove alcohol.

Your honor please, the important thing about the factual situation here is that after this conversation and identification of exhibits at police headquarters the fire department personnel withdrew from the fire scene leaving the premises unguarded and unlocked, for four hours.

Now, some time later that day July 20 – I am sorry January 22, I can not tell you because the record does not show at what time of day, the premises were locked by the fire department but they were locked and they were boarded up and there is ample photographs in the record to show you exactly what that building looked like in its boarded up condition and they were secured from outsiders coming in.
It was done by lieutenant Summer Will of the fire department.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Just to understand that what your view of the record might be perhaps it is not a issue here suppose the fire department or the investigators had got a magistrate and said we want authority to search the building, they went there the morning immediately after the fire, and said and here is what we found and here is what we want.
We want authority to search, we want authority to board up the building to avoid any destruction of evidence, would there have been ample bases for a warrant issue?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: For warrant--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In your view?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: For administrative warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, for a judicial warrant.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: For the judicial warrant.
From my own personal experience any time you have gasoline present a fire scene suspected of being the accelerant, I believe that provides a reasonable cause to --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So if they had gone to the Magistrate, you think the warrant could have issued for further searching --

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I believe that under that state of facts that a reasonable Magistrate would have authorized the warrant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if they have not found any gasoline but simply felt that their investigation was incomplete because of the smoky conditions and so forth, what is your contention that a Magistrate would have had to find if they had gone before on the next morning and asked for a leave to continue the investigation.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I believe that the fact that the fire personnel cannot determine the cause and origin of fire would be a legitimate basis for granting an administrative warrant to enter the premises, to determine what exact to do -- what the cause and origin is, if it is possible to be done.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what if the Magistrate were to conclude that the diligent fire personnel could have concluded it at four in the morning, would he be permitted under the Federal Constitution to turn down a warrant at that point on that basis.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Assuming the standard which you have given me to be factual then I would have to say that there would be no necessity.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And only necessity would warrant the issuance of the type of administrative warrant we have been discussing --.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I believe so because I think that is the only reason that it exists.
The Fire Department is charged with a responsibly to keep track of the cause of the fire.

They are unable to do that in a particular situation and the owner would not give them consent to enter the premises then I believe that provides a legitimate basis to ask for an administrative search warrant and it does not impose a serious hardship or difficulty upon the Fire Department.
It does provide an additional safeguard and that a Magistrate now sits between the Fire Department or Police Department and their search for the cause and origin of the fire.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What do you call an Administrative warrant if you are talking about the Magistrate.
That is a Judicial warrant.
Isn't it?
It is not just a warrant issued by the Executive Branch or the Administrative Branch.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well, perhaps the Court is not aware that Michigan in the same Act which was cited in the briefs and petitions to justify the Fire Marshal's entering the premises also has another section right following it which gives the Fire Marshal the right to investigate crime.

If he thinks one is precedent, part of that Statute grants immunity if the witness is called to produce and give testimony against himself and the procedure is there and it is in the Fire Act to safeguard the right of the person who is being called upon to produce evidence, to explain the cause and origin of the fire.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well this gentleman was away for a week or eight days, was he not?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Yes he was Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well should they then stop all their inquiry under the fire clause until he got back?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No I think they had ample grounds and basis in this record to go to the Magistrate and ask for a warrant for a Criminal Investigation.
Not just an administrative but a criminal because they found gasoline.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if at that time they did not think in terms of a Criminal Investigation.
A lot of people leave gasoline in cans lying around.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well, I think the record will reflect the opposite Your Honor because Chief See and Detective were both indicated in cross examination in their opinion at that point in time, they suspected foul play and they believe that Arson had been committed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So that you are saying as soon as they began to have suspicions then they must get a traditional warrant.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well I am saying that as soon as there is a reasonable basis for those suspicions, yes, not just a mere fact that they have private suspicion but the fact that they have to go to a Magistrate and lay those suspicions out and what they consist of and if there is a reasonable basis for them and if that reasonable basis is the presence of gasoline, I say the Magistrate should issue a warrant.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The Supreme Court of Michigan I take it in construing the Act that you referred to in the Administrative warrant provision that I understood you to say was contained and held that was inadequate under the Federal Constitution.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No I do not believe the Supreme Court of Michigan reviewed the fire Marshal's Act to determine whether or not it was adequate.
All they have determined is that in this particular instance, the search and seizure in this case was unreasonable and in violation of the Constitutional Right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But did not they say the Statute did not speak to this point.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Oh yes, oh yes, in terms of requiring a warrant.
That is correct Your Honor.
They make that comment in their opinion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr Bacalis, I have one problem, you could actually help me with, the key to the premises was retained by the public authority, usually the Fire Marshal--

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did the owner of the premises or the tenant have access at all?
Or did he demand access at all, it is kind of a strange privacy interest where he can get his own -- ?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: The last page of our Appendix indicates the owner's statement, he could not get a thing out of that building.
The fire department had in effect seized and sealed it off.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well did he asked for it?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did he ask to get in?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything in this record that would convince any of us that he had not abandoned that building?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: There is no indication in the record that he did abandon the building, none whatsoever.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That was my question.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Was there any evidence in the record that he had not abandoned the building?
He locked up the building and went overseas?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And what did he do to get in the building after that?
Nothing.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: The record reflects that he went to the building and that there was various points in time when anyone may enter the building because the vandal would frequently pull apart the board which boarded up the windows and freely enter the building.
And in this manner, he had entered the building himself, I am sure, now the record does not reflect that he did enter.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, if you please, I want the record on this. Is there anything in the record that shows that he tried to get in the building?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: The record would reflect that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the next question is, is there anything that he did to keep anybody out of the building?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: The only things that he did to keep people out of the building is not -- the statements of what he did prior to the fire occurred.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You are talking about after the fire occurred.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: The record does not contain any evidences as to what he did to protect the building from invasion by anyone.
That is right.
There is absolutely no disclosure in the record as to that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Neither did he put up a sign to say private property?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No sir, not in this record.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did he make any effort to remove the contents of the building like the furniture that had not been sold presumably something was not damaged?
I do not know.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well, so far as the furniture and the contents that were in the building were concerned, they were fairly well destroyed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They were, I see.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Sir.

The things which were not destroyed of course were the business records and there is evidence in the record that the fire department and or the police department, no I guess it was the State police, State Fire Marshall's division took a box of records, business records to the fingerprint laboratory for purposes of having fingerprints taken off.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It seems to me, it is a kind of a strange privacy interest where an owner does not even ask to get his records back or anything back and let somebody else have the key to the place for about a month.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: The record would reflect that Sergeant Hoffman who is from the State Fire Marshall's office told my client Mr. Tyler, he was not to remove anything from the building, that is in the record.
In fact, when they went there to get on January 29th, there is a discussion between them and it is on the record to that effect.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was there any Statutory authority for a public official taking possession of premises like these?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Not in my opinion.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, did you make any move in any Court to get possession of the building?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well like I said Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is a very simple answer.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No we did not go into Court because we did not need to.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But he did not have possession?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No.
Your Honor please, what happened was the police and firemen locked up the building but vandals kept breaking it open.
Anyone could and did that if they wanted to go into that building.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well was your client denied access to the building?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: He was denied the right to remove documents from, evidence from the building according to Sergeant Hoffman.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did you do anything to get him access to the building?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I did not, I do not think I represented him at that time Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well did anybody do anything to get him access to the building?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Not according to the record.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well how can you tell me he had not abandoned it?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Because he was still paying rent on the building Your Honor.
And that is in the record.
Not only he was paying rent on the building, he had his records.
What was remaining of his business records in the file and Sergeant Hoffman told him, he was not to take those from the building because he wanted to preserve them as evidence.
My client not knowing any better yield it to his direction an order.
Now I did not goto Court and ask for an order to receive those records.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you said you did not represent him at that time?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I know, I understand it, nor did anyone else according to the record.

The thing that intrigues me about this case is the fact that the State Supreme Court has justifiably concluded from the testimony of the participants that this was in fact a criminal investigation from the early morning hours of January 22nd beginning with Chief See's declaration as to what the cause and origin was.

I think that is significant when you view what was done here by the authorities as the government's representative in literally sealing of this building and keeping the occupant from his records, that in effect we have not only a specific seizure but we have a total seizure of all business records and the so called tools of the crime.

Now unfortunately, my brothers want a bootstrap, the jury determination that there was an arson committed by my clients to say that because of such a determination, they have no expectation of privacy which this court or the constitution of Michigan or of United States protect and that to me is nothing more than saying that the -- and justifies the means, and I just cannot accept that kind of reasoning to say that there cannot be any expectation of privacy simply because there has been a determination that an arson has been convened.

It also runs up against the presumption of innocence when this representative of the government is seeking evidence, if he forms an opinion whether it be reasonable or not that the occupant has been guilty of the crime of arson, that should not by itself extinguish any expectation of privacy nor should it give the government the right to intrude as it did in this case totally by sealing off the premises.
Particularly, under circumstances of where we have the department, both the fire department and the police department involved.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Does the sealing of the premises add anything more to your argument that would not be present if the fire department had simply come in at these additional dates and taken the additional evidence?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Only to the extent of the scope of the invasion Your Honor, because I think they took more than they needed to take in terms of a reasonable search that they had want in the first place.
Let us assume they had a warrant to search for a criminal cause in the first place, I do not believe that would give them the right to take possession of entire premises.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Oh you may well be right but I get the impression from the record that your client was not overly concerned.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well, unfortunately we did not develop that in evidence.
That is correct, there is nothing in the record to indicate one way or the other, how my client felt about it?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, is it likely that he would have wanted a lot of cardboard furniture returned, do you think?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well, I do not know about the cardboard furniture but I do know about his business Your Honor.

I am sure that one would have a hard time convincing this court that he would want his cardboard deposits in the fire scene to be returned but of more significance are his private records, his business records.
Because now we are talking about possible Fifth Amendment implications.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does the record indicate any condition of inherent dangerousness after the fire in the structure?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: There is absolutely in the record to indicate there was inherit danger present after the fire department left the scene.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you say that the fire department or the some public authority had an obligation to try to seal that building and lock it and protect in from vandalism until the owner could take over that responsibility himself?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No I did not say that Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No I say would you say so.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No I do not think so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think they should just walk away and leave the doors open?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I can guarantee you Your Honor they do it everyday in Michigan, everyday--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Bacalis, your emphasis on the business records I can not recall, were they admitted in the evidence?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No Your Honor.
But they were seized.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But then, they are not really before us.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: No I only offer that as an extent of the scope of the intrusion here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But is it not the constitutional question that we are supposed to decide here, precisely the same as if there had never been any business record in the place at all?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well, that part is true Your Honor, but I think in looking at what took place I thought it would be helpful to the court to understand the scope of the invasion by the governmental authority.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But for all we know on this record they may have returned those papers and records to him as soon as he came and claimed them.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: There is nothing in the record one way or the other Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well suppose Mr. Bacalis, there has been no gasoline found in the course of putting out the fire, no evidence of the cause at that time but the fire department has a duty to determine cause, whether there is a crime suspected or not so the fire department does or does the next day get in a so called administrative warrant but it nevertheless comes back either with or without the warrant looks around the property and it determines cause right there on the spot and it determines it from the fact that finds some gas and unimpeachable evidence that there was arson and it finds the cause and it takes away, is that admissible in evidence?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I do not believe it is Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that you think that without a warrant, without a probable cause warrant issued by a magistrate, the public authorities are entitled to determine cause but if they find evidence of a crime they cannot admit it?
They cannot introduce it unless they have a warrant.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Not unless they obtained that evidence through the means of a warrant, that is correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if instead of taking something they merely took photographs of objective factors that would be evidence in support of arson would those photographs be admissible without a warrant?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I believe that they would be improper Your Honor because they represent a search, they do not represent a seizure but at least the represent the search.
The photograph is the next best substitute for giving a visual presentation to the triar.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well I suppose instead of taking pictures the Fire Marshall's man who makes these investigation to determine cause of fire merely looks at them, sees them makes notes and remembers them and they tender him as a witness would you say his testimony is excludable?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I would think so Your Honor on the theory of search being just what it is, a search and without a warrant, I do not want to appear to not acknowledge that when the fire department is there for the purpose of putting out the fire.
They have every right in the world to look and see what is there to be seen.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And if they see some evidence of what caused the fire, even though it might indicate a crime, they can take it.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: At the time they are there for putting out the fire yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All you are saying is that if they are legally on the premises they can cease evidence of crime that in plain sight.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: That is right and that is why.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But what about the next day if they are legally on the premises and if there is an evidence.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: If they are legally on the premises and I assume by that Your Honor means they have obtained a warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, no, let us assume that suppose they have no evidence the night before that there has been any crime committed but they must determine cause, are you not suggesting they need to show probable cause of some crime before they can go back on the premises to determine the cause they can at least get an administrative warrant and go back in.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well suppose they get the administrative warrant as you call it whatever that is and they are legally on the premises, you would agree they are legally on the premises?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Yes under those circumstances.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well and then they find some evidence.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well I think then that is part of being in the on the premises in the lawful function.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Legally, so they could then introduce their evidence that they legally find.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Yes sir I believe so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Who issues this administrative warrant as you speak out of under Michigan law?
And how do you distinguish an administrative warrant from judicial warrant or traditional warrant?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: Well unfortunately there is nothing spelled out in the statute in reference to a procedure as to what magistrate to go before to obtain warrant in an administrative area.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well is there in then in Michigan law any such thing as an administrative warrant that would be creature of statute would it not?

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: I think the whole phraseology has come out of the Camara decisions in terms of recognizing a differentiation between an administrative search of the premises and a criminal search and from that distinction has now emerged the new language administrative warrant.
Unfortunately so far as I know, there is no legislative pronouncements as to how that is to be implemented nor at this point are there any judicial decisions that spell out how it should be done.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or Maybe all this Court had in mind in that conversation in the opinion was that States could enact legislation, creating an administrative warrant procedure, but if you do not have a statute of Michigan authorizing an administrative warrant then I wonder why any discussion of the administrative warrant is relevant here.

turn.speaker: jesse_r_bacalis
turn.label: Mr. Jesse R. Bacalis
turn.text: We do have a statute which is been alluded to already Your Honor, which allows the Fire Marshall if he suspects a crime a procedure of testimony and subpoena by which he can require people to bring in records and evidence and part of that statute also grants immunity to anybody who brings in such evidence.
